p.s: Sonnet 60 is a poem written by the EnglischEnglish poet and playwright William Shakespeare born in 1564 and died 1616.
It ws most likely written in the 1590s, but it was not published until 1609, like most of his sonnets.
Like many of Shakespeare's sonnets, Sonnet 60 is a love poem, discussing the passage of time.
It is part of the Fair Youth sequence, a series of poems that are believed to be adressedaddressed to unnamed young man.
The ShakespearanShakespearean sonnet is made of three quatrains and a rhyming couplet ending the sonnet, concludes 14 lines each containing 10 or 11 syllables.
It has an ABAB CDCD EFEF GG rhyme scheme and is composed in iambic pentameter.
In the following I am going to analyse to giving sonnet on it'sits content and form.

In the first quatrain, which usually sets the subject of the sonnet, the passage of time is mentioned so do our minutes hasten to ther end (l. 2) which is compared to waves slowly reaching forward to hitting the shres.
With a metaphor set in nature the lyrical voice displays how naturally it is for age to pass by.

In the second quatrain the lyrical voice begins with the birth of Jesus Christ Nativity, once in the main of light (l. 5) which is aan intended pun, because Jesus is seen as the light of the world or comparable to the glimpse of hope for humanity.
So the sentence culd be translated to The light, once in the main of light, which has a sense of sarcasm because if one is the light you are not once in the main of light but always.

The second line of the second quatrain says crawls to maturity (l. 6) whereby crawling could be seen as a metaphor for the processes of growing up, because baby's first start crawling in the early age of leaning and as they grow older they start to mature.
In line 8 you can see the mention of time again And time that gave [...] which could prove that the sonnet discusses the passage of time.

Moreover, in the third quatrain of the donnet it first seems like the lyrical voice is talking about nature but in the last line of the quatrain one could hint that he is actually alking about death, which can be indicated by [...] his scythe to mow (l. 12).
The scythe is not only seen as a tool to cut grass but also as a symbol of death used by a black dressed silhouette called Sensenmann in German.
This quatrain has a twist to it because it suddenly talks about mortality.
The final couplet attempts to conclude the sonnet.
The lyrical voice says that he hopes that his loveslove stays in rememberance, also if he dies.
With [...] despite his cruel hand (l. 14) the lyrical I means the death which uses his hands or scythe to take lifeslives.
Concluding, I would say that the sonnet discusses the topics of passage of age leading/shifting towards mortality.
At the beginning of the second quatrain, he mentions birth, with the birth of Jesus Christ Nativity and at the end of the third quatrain he speaks about that.
ThisThese two quatrains could display the process of life.
Moreover, the author of the sonnet makes use of a wordfield strongly based on nature e.g. waves, shore or naure's truth.
Striking stylistic devices Shakespeare uses here are metaphors.
